content.question: The spheres are isolated from all other objects, and sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is then released from rest. The student says that, assuming the gravitational forces between the spheres are negligible, the kinetic energy of sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> just before it hits sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be determined by multiplying the electric force exerted on sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>X</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> at its original position by the distance it moves. Is the student correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because force times distance equals work, and the work equals the change in kinetic energy.
Yes, because the electric force is the only force exerted if gravity is negligible.

No, because the calculation of work must take into account the fact that the force on sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>X</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> changes as it moves.
No, because the change in kinetic energy can only be determined from the change in potential energy of the system.
